PixelToaster::Timer

Timer Class Reference

List of all members.

Detailed Description

A high resolution timer.

The most common use for a timer is to keep track of the current time, and the delta time each frame you render to the display. This lets you make sure your program is framerate independent, in other words, it runs at the same speed no matter the framerate.

Here is a simple example:

        Display display( "timer example", 320, 240 );

        Timer timer;

        while ( display.open() )
        {
            const double time = timer.time();
            const double delta = timer.delta();

            // advance animation forward by delta seconds...
        }

Note:
The timer uses doubles instead of floats to ensure maximum precision is available.


Public Member Functions

 Timer ()
 The default constructor sets the current time to zero and starts the timer.

 Resets current time to zero.

Member Function Documentation

double time (  )  [inline]

Get current time.

Returns:
current time in seconds.

double delta (  )  [inline]

Get time elapsed since last call.

Note:
if this is the first call to Timer::delta since you created the timer, or called reset, then delta time is equivalent to time elapsed since the timer was started.
Returns:
delta time in seconds.

double resolution (  )  [inline]

Get timer resolution.

The timer resolution is the smallest change in time that can be detected.

Returns:
timer resolution in seconds.

void wait ( double  seconds  )  [inline]

Wait for a period of time.

Parameters:
seconds the number of seconds to wait before returning from this method.
